Fig. 1 A summary scheme of the reactor. Figure 1: Fig. 2 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77K for (a) monometallic and (b) bimetallic catalysts, as well as, BJH pore size distribution (PSD) for (c) monometallic and (d) bimetallic catalysts, and HK micropore size distribution for (e) monometallic and (f) bimetallic catalysts. Figure 2: Fig. 3 XRD patterns for (a) Ni monometallic and (b) Ni-W bimetallic catalysts. Figure 3: Fig. 4 Raman shifts spectra for (a) monometallic and (b) bimetallic catalysts. Figure 4: Fig. 5 (a)-(d) HR-SEM images of the bimetallic catalysts and (e)-(f) EDX analysis (obtained after area scanning) for selected bimetallic catalysts. Figure 5: Fig. 6 HR-TEM (a), (b) images of r- NiO-WO3-ZY30; with (c) EDX analysis; (d) low magnification HAADF STEM; with a (e) HAADF-STEM showing an area for Ni and W mapping; and the corresponding EELS elemental maps of (f) Ni, (g) W, and (h) O. The circles show regions corresponding to: pure Ni nanoparticles (red), pure W nanoparticles (green) and alloyed Ni-W nanoparticles (yellow). Figure 6: Fig. 7 XPS core level spectra of: (a) Ni 2p, (b) W 4f, (c) Si 2p, and (d) O 1s for r-NiO-ZY30 and r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 catalysts. This study investigated the effect of the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio in the range of 5-80 in zeolite Y (ZY) as a support for the bi-functional reaction of heptane hydrocracking. Bi-metallicity impact, through the addition of W on Ni in the supported metal catalysts was also examined. The catalytic activity was assessed at 350°C and 400°C in order to deduce an optimized composition of the catalyst in terms of metal composition and Si/Al ratio. The results were correlated to the catalysts’ surface and bulk properties, the latter after employing a number of material characterization techniques. It was shown that Ni-W bimetallic catalysts demonstrated better catalytic activity (conversion, 78% to 91%) than Ni-based monometallic counterpart catalysts (conversion, 74.2% to 82.7%), with NiO-WO3-ZY30 (SiO2/Al2O3 ratio equal to 30) exhibiting the highest conversion. This was attributed to the bimetallic's enhanced metal dispersion and smaller particle size, evaluated using temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of H2 and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) imaging. The stronger acidity, as quantified by total acidity calculations, of zeolite Y having higher Si/Al ratio, and their balanced ratio of micro- and meso-porosity played a vital role in their catalytic performance. This study provides useful design guidelines on how to adjust both the Si/Al ratio in the zeolite Y support and the catalyst's bimetallicity for enhanced hydrocracking performance. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydroprocessing Surface acidity Hydrocracking Bi-functional catalyst Bimetallic Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrocracking is a well-known process in petrochemical industries that transforms heavy fuel molecules into lighter, value-added products [1]. Amongst the main components in optimizing this process is the proper design of the catalyst used. Although a wide range of catalysts are reported in the literature, such as metal oxides and supported zeolites, a suitable selection depends on a number of factors including the feed type (fuel to be hydrocracked), and the reaction conditions, such as temperature and pressure. Despite these differences, the use of a bi-functional catalyst, in which the acidic support provides the C-C cracking function, while the deposited metal nanoparticles provide the hydrogenation-dehydrogenation function, has been reported to have pronounced benefits, such as controlling the selectivity and activity of the reaction. Zeolites in general, and zeolite Y in particular, are widely used as supporting material for hydrocracking catalysts, as they provide a number of desirable characteristics such as high surface area, increased porosity, strong acidity, high thermal and hydrothermal stability and lower carbon deposition tendency [2,3]. In fact, the porosity of the zeolites induces their shape selectivity, which highly impacts the reaction pathways/mechanism and thus the products formed, since some reactions are permitted while others are suppressed as a result. While conventional zeolites provide one level of porosity, that is, microporosity, hierarchical zeolites are known for exhibiting more than one porosity level, usually microporosity and mesoporosity, and sometimes macroporosity [4]. Thus, hierarchical zeolites have gained the interest of researchers as they allow improved access of reactant molecules to the active sites of the catalyst, solving the diffusion limitation issue of larger molecules induced by microporous zeolites [5,6]. Therefore, the composition of the catalyst is vital for controlling the reaction performance in terms of conversion, selectivity, and yield. Zeolite Y is a ubiquitous type of zeolite for hydrocracking because of its relatively high stability and activity at elevated temperatures, in addition to its high Si/Al ratio achieved after post-synthetic treatment forming an ultra-stable form [3]. Differences in Si/Al ratio in zeolites usually affect the amount and distribution of Si–O–Al groups in their crystal structures, causing significant alterations to their properties [7,8]. Higher Si/Al ratio zeolites have more Si–O–Si than Si–O–Al linkages, and vice versa for lower Si/Al ratios zeolites [9]. These two linkages determine bond angles and lengths around the acid site [10], the distance of close Si–O–Al or Si–O–Si groups within the zeolite structural framework [11], as well as the type of guest molecules and electronic charge distribution in the structural framework [12]. These factors in turn influence the electrostatic potential and the strength of binding cations interaction on negative charge sites in the framework, affecting the H+ protonation [9]. Therefore, variations in Si/Al ratios lead to significant variations in the zeolites’ protonation, and thus to their acidity. It has been reported that faujasite zeolites (a family of zeolites to which zeolite Y belongs) of lower Si/Al ratio possess higher protonation, i.e. weaker acidity [9]. However, it is vital here to differentiate between the number of acid sites and their acidity strength. When Al substitutes Si in a tetrahedral zeolite framework, it forces a negative charge on the Al, which should be compensated by a cation that is quite often a proton (H+). Since a proton is a strong Brønsted acid, decreasing the Si/Al ratio increases the number of acid sites in the framework if the cation sites are occupied by protons. Yet, as the population of protons increases, each acid site becomes a quite weaker Brønsted site. In turn, Lewis acidity in zeolites, although much weaker than Brønsted acidity, is typically generated from extra-framework Al that is not tetrahedrally bound in the framework. A lower Si/Al ratio and crystal size has greater concentration of extra-framework Al species with Lewis acidity [13]. Thus, higher Si/Al ratio zeolites are more stable and are less prone to framework degradation upon preparing them into acidic form, causing their stronger Brønsted acidity (even if the number of these sites is lower) [13]. A recent investigation of the effect of Si/Al ratio zeolites in Ni-W catalysts for second stage hydrocracking of UCO and squalane (C30H62), concluded that an increase of this ratio resulted in a decrease in catalytic activity and an increase in selectivity to middle distillates [14]. This performance was attributed to the lower concentration of Brønsted acid sites in the zeolites. In a different study, the effect of framework Si/Al ratio on the intrinsic activity of Brønsted acid sites in zeolite Y was examined [15] and it was shown that higher Si/Al ratio samples demonstrated relatively higher cracking rates of propane per gram and per acid site. In general, catalytic activity increases with an increase in the number of Brønsted acid sites, as revealed by the poisoning and the chemical substitution of Al by Si in the zeolite framework [16]. However, the catalytic activity declines faster than the number of poisoned sites, indicating that not all of the Brønsted acid sites contribute to activity, and thus higher activity of the high-silica samples are attributed to the number of Brønsted acid sites that take part in the reaction; i.e. more catalytically active sites [15]. Thus, the superior activity of the samples with higher Si/Al ratios is ascribed to the formation of more isolated Brønsted acid sites. Heptane, C7H16, was used as probe molecule for the hydrocracking reaction in several studies in the literature in which a variety of composite catalyst compositions were used [17–20]. While hydrocracking of heptane is considered a model reaction, it is carried out herein to demonstrate basic catalyst design concepts, which should also be applicable to hydrocracking of heavier paraffinic molecules. For example, hydrocracking of n-heptane and n-hexane were studied on an activated WO3/TiO2 catalyst, in which the catalytic activity was evaluated. At a reaction temperature of 598 K, β-scission was favored in the case of n-heptane while isomerization was favored for n-hexane. The research octane number (RON) was also improved for n-hexane from 24.8 to 70–80 for hexane isomers, and from zero for n-heptane to cracking products with a high octane number [17]. In a recent study, a Ni-promoted zeolite Y catalyst was doped with graphene nanoplatelets (GNPs) and tested for heptane hydrocracking at different temperatures. These GNP-doped catalysts possessed high stability with time-on-stream and catalytic conversion of 81.6% and 83.3% at 350°C and 400°C, respectively [21]. Moreover, the incorporation of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) into Ni-based zeolite Y hydrocracking catalyst increased the heptane conversion by 22% at 350 °C, and showed reduced coke formation upon the reaction [22]. Other studies reported the use of bimetallic-based catalysts, particularly, NiO-WO3/Zeolite Y for heptane hydrocracking, in which the zeolite particles were ball milled into the nano-size [19,23,24]. The nano-sized zeolites exhibited higher BET surface area and enhanced catalytic conversion compared to their micro-sized counterparts. Particularly, the conversion of n-heptane molecules ranged between 34.63% (for micro-sized zeolites at 400°C) and 98.32% (for nano-sized zeolites at 350°C). The performance of various zeolite-based catalysts for hydrocracking are compared and discussed thoroughly in a recent review paper [20] for a wide range of feeds. The hydrogenation component of the bifunctional catalyst is often a mixed phase of groups VI and VIII metals. The Ni-W combination is very attractive in hydrogenation of aromatic cycles and in hydrodenitrogenation reactions, and there are studies that showed how the optimum ratio of these metals would lead to enhanced catalytic performance [25]. The optimum Ni/W ratio for hydrocracking experiments depends on the corresponding support, and the amount of Ni species required for promoting the catalyst varies based on the interactions between the deposited metal species and the support [25]. However, the range of optimized Ni/W ratio was reported in a number of studies to be within 0.25 and 0.36 for higher catalytic activities in hydrocracking [25,26]. Moreover, sulfided metals are frequently used to provide the hydro-dehydrogenation function in hydrocracking catalysts with high resistance against poisoning [27]. Yet, since pure heptane (lacking any sulfur or nitrogen compounds) is used as the feed in this study, catalyst deactivation by poisoning is not a concern here, and thus non-sulfided metals can be used. In this study, we report on 5wt.% M(Ni, Ni-W)/zeolite Y type of catalysts with emphasis on the effect of two important structural parameters of the catalysts and their subsequent impact on the performance for heptane hydrocracking. In particular, the effect of (a) varying the Si/Al ratio in the zeolite Y (support), and (b) having monometallic (Ni) or bimetallic (Ni, W) active (metal) sites are both studied in an attempt to optimize the catalyst functionality for the reaction at hand. Although there are reports on the effects of each of the above structural parameters individually, the simultaneous study of both is still an open matter in the literature. The reaction metrics, such as conversion (X) and selectivity (S) towards various reaction products such as smaller paraffin molecules, are critically discussed in relation to the bulk and surface properties of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Zeolite Y with different Si/Al ratios were purchased from Zeolyst International having commercial names of CBV400, CBV720, CBV760, CBV780 corresponding to SiO2/Al2O3 ratios of 5.1, 30, 60, and 80; herein, these are referred to as ZY5, ZY30, ZY60, and ZY80 respectively, for convenience. It is worth noting that these SiO2/Al2O3 ratios correspond to molar Si/Al ratios of 2.6, 15, 30, and 40, respectively. Ni-ZY (5, 30, 60, 80) monometallic catalysts synthesis: Nickel (Ni) was first impregnated on each of the four different zeolite Y supports, separately, using nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate, Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (Aldrich, >98.5%) as precursor, following the wet impregnation method. Ni precursor and zeolite amounts were selected such to achieve 5 wt.% Ni on the zeolite support. After wet impregnation, the four catalysts were dried for 12 hours at 120°C and then cooled at room temperature. The obtained catalysts were then calcined in air at 500°C for 5 hours to obtain NiO-ZY(5, 30, 60, 80), which were later reduced in H2 at 550°C in situ prior to the catalytic testing in order to obtain Ni nanoparticles on the zeolite, named, r-NiO-ZY5, r-NiO-ZY30, r-NiO-ZY60, r-NiO-ZY80. Ni-W-ZY (5, 30, 60, 80) bimetallic catalysts synthesis: In this case, the wet impregnation was repeated, as described in the monometallic synthesis for the four zeolite Y supports, but with the co-presence of Ni and W as to achieve a total metal loading of 5 wt.% (Ni:W in 1:3 ratio [26,28]). The precursors used were nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate, Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (Aldrich, >98.5%), and ammonium metatungstate (AMT), (NH4)6[H2W12O40].xH2O (Aldrich, >85%). The catalysts were then dried and calcined under the same conditions explained earlier, forming NiO-WO3-ZY(5, 30, 60, 80). These were later reduced in situ prior to the catalytic testing as to obtain r-NiO-WO3-ZY5, r-NiO-WO3-ZY30, r-NiO-WO3-ZY60, r-NiO-WO3-ZY80. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 BET surface area The monometallic and bimetallic catalysts’ total specific surface areas and porosities were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption at 77 K, using a 3Flex Physisorption porosimeter (Micrometrics, Atlanta, USA). The Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method and t-plots were applied to find the surface areas and micropore volume measurements of the materials, respectively. Also, the Barrett, Joyner and Halenda (BJH) method was used to obtain the pore size distribution of the studied catalysts, while the Horvath​-Kawazoe (HK) method was utilized for determining micropore size distribution. Prior to the adsorption-desorption measurements, the materials were placed under vacuum for degassing at 120°C for 12 hours to remove any previously adsorbed gases in the pores of the catalysts. The instrumental error in the porosity measurements is around 0.075 cm3 for volume and 0.294 m2 for surface area [29]. Also, the t-plot statistical thickness method was applied for finding the micropore volume. This requires the determination of the thickness of the adsorbate layer N2 as a function of relative pressure, p/p 0. The statistical thickness was then predicted using the de Boer equation [30]: (1) t ( A ) = [ 13.99 0.034 − log ( P / P o ) ] 1 / 2 . Then, the average pore diameter was estimated by the ratio 4V T/S BET , where V T is the total volume and S BET is the surface area [31]. 2.2.2 X-ray diffraction X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) analysis was employed to study the crystalline structure of the fresh catalysts using the Bruker D2 Phaser XRD with a radiation wavelength of 1.54184 Å (Cu-Kα) at 30 kV and 10 mA between 2θ angles of 5˚ and 80˚ 2.2.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) was then utilized to investigate the elemental oxidation states and chemical environment of the catalysts. The analysis was done on a ThermoFisher Scientific Instruments (East Grinstead, UK) K-Alpha+ spectrometer with a monochromated Al Kα X-ray source (hν= 1486.6 eV). An X-ray spot of 400 μm and a pass energy of 50 eV were used for recording high-resolution core level spectra. All spectra were charge referenced against the C 1s peak at 285.0 eV for charge correction purposes. In addition, elemental quantification was completed using the high resolution, core level spectra after the removal of a non-linear (Shirley) background. The ThermoFisher Scientific Advantage software includes the appropriate sensitivity factors and adjusts for the electron energy analyzer transmission function. 2.2.4 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy, in turn, was used to detect the vibrations in the chemical bonds of the studied materials, where the analysis was performed on a Raman-AFM combination Witec Alpha300 RA, using a laser wavelength of 532 nm, and a 50x objective. This resulted in a spatial resolution of 590 nm, and the analysis was carried out for the range of 50-1000 cm−1. 2.2.5 Scanning/Transmission electron microscopy imaging (SEM/TEM) High resolution scanning electron microscopy (HR-SEM) was used to observe the morphologies of the particles on an FEI Nova NanoSEM 650. Furthermore, a silicon drift detector (SDD) energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was utilized to analyze the specimens’ elemental chemistry on a dual beam scanning electron microscope (SEM) that is also equipped with a focused ion beam (FIB). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was carried out first using an FEI Tecnai instrument with a line resolution of 0.20 nm, and then advanced analyses was carried out using Titan 80-300 ST, operated at 300 kV and equipped with a spherical aberration (Cs) corrector for the image (CEOS CETCOR), and an energy filter (model GIF Quantum 963, Gatan, Inc.). The elemental composition of the materials was obtained after using X-ray energy dispersive (EDX) spectroscopy, while nanoscale elemental mapping was determined after using electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), in combination with the scanning TEM (STEM) mode. TEM data acquisition and processing was achieved by employing Gatan Microscopy Suite (GMS) software (version 3.2). 2.2.6 Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of NH3 Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (TPD-NH3) was done in a chemisorption AutoChem 2920 unit (Micrometrics) for the fresh catalysts to investigate their surface acidity. The steps involved in TPD-NH3 were as follows. He gas flow was passed while ramping the temperature to 400°C at a rate of 30°C/min and kept for 1 h. The temperature was then reduced to 30°C at a rate of 30°C/min. The feed was then switched to 2% NH3 in He and kept flowing for 1 hour (adsorption step). After this adsorption step, a switch to He gas-flow was made and kept at 25°C until the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) signal stabilized. The temperature of the solid was then increased to 700°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min (desorption) while recording the TCD signal. Calibration of the TCD signal was done using the gas mixture used in the ammonia TPD (2% NH3 in He), where the gas was injected incrementally to create the calibration curve, so to calculate the surface acidity in mmol/g. 2.2.7 Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of H2 Temperature-programmed desorption of hydrogen TPD-H2 was carried out in a chemisorption AutoChem 2920 unit (Micrometrics) for the fresh NiO-ZY30 and NiO-WO3-ZY30 catalysts to evaluate the surface exposed metal (metal dispersion, D m%). The steps involved in TPD-H2 were as follows: H2 was first allowed to flow for metal reduction while ramping the temperature to 550 °C at a rate of 30 °C/min and kept flowing for 150 min. The temperature was then reduced to 30 °C while flowing Ar at a rate of 30 °C /min. 10% H2 in Ar was then allowed to flow and kept for 60 min (adsorption). Then Ar was passed for 20 min, and recording started while ramping the temperature to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C /min (desorption). Finally, the sample was cooled to room temperature. The metal dispersion was calculated using Eq. (2) [32,33], and the average crystallite diameter, d, was calculated from the metal dispersion, D m, using Eqs. (2)-(3), assuming that the crystals are all spherical and have the same dimensions [34]: (2) D m = V C h e m / 22 , 414 x S F x M W ( m x p ) / 100 x 100 (3) d ( nm ) = 97.1 / ( D m % ) where D m represents the metal dispersion percentage, V Chem is the adsorption amount (cm3), m is the sample mass (g), p is the weight percent of metal content in the catalyst (wt%), MW is the molar weight of metal (g/mol), SF is stoichiometry factor representing metal atoms per H2 molecule [35]. 2.3 Catalytic testing Heptane hydrocracking experiments were performed in an Autoclave Engineers BTRS high temperature and high-pressure testing system, equipped with a high-pressure HPLC pump (Series I) and metering valves to regulate the flow rate of liquid and gas feed, respectively. Procedure: A continuous flow, fixed bed, tubular stainless steel reactor (a summary scheme is shown in Fig. 1 ) was used in the experiments with an internal diameter of 0.7 cm, length of 30 cm and volume of 12 mL. For both the monometallic and bimetallic catalyst systems, reduction in 100 v/v % of H2 (50 mL/min) in atmospheric pressure was carried out in situ prior to catalytic testing. The system was then set to the desired reaction temperature under a flow of high purity N2 (100 mL/min) and pressurized with H2 at 5 bar. Heptane >99 % solution was injected to the system at a rate of 0.035 mL/min, along with a flow of H2. Liquid and gaseous products were passed through a liquid-gas separator, placed downstream from the catalyst bed; liquid products were then manually collected for analysis (GC/MS), whereas the gas stream was sent to the GC. The heptane hydrocracking experiments were carried out using two different reaction temperatures, 350 and 400°C, H2 pressure of 5 bar, Liquid Hourly Space Velocity (LHSV) of 4.2 h−1, and H2/heptane ratio of 3:1. These conditions were chosen in line with previous studies on heptane hydrocracking [19,36]. Each test was conducted for 3 hours using a fresh catalyst, and the liquid products were analyzed at 1 h intervals. Moreover, stability tests were performed for 20 hour time-on-stream for each catalyst. Product analysis: The liquid samples were analyzed on an Agilent 7890A/5975C Triple-Axis Detector diffusion pump Gas Chromatographer - Mass Spectrometer (GC-MS) equipped with an Agilent Multimode inlet. High injection and column temperatures were used to directly analyze n-Alkanes so as to avoid chemical derivatization. The split/splitless injector was operated in split mode with split ratio 25:1 and split flow 50 mL/min using deactivated open ended helix liner (Agilent Technologies). The temperature of the inlet was 300°C for the duration of the analysis and the volume of the samples injected was 1 μL. The oven temperature program was initially set at 30°C for 8 min and then it was increased by 8°C/min to 250°C. The maximum temperature was maintained for 5 min and the total run time was 40 min. An Agilent 30m x 320 μm x 0.1 μm J&W DB5-HT capillary column (5% phenyl, 95% methylpolysiloxane) was employed to achieve chromatographic separation, operated under a constant flow rate mode of He (2 mL/min). The temperature of the ion source, the quadrupole and the MS interface for both instruments were 230, 150 and 330°C, respectively. The GC/MSD Chemstation software was used to obtain chromatographic data. The gaseous reaction products were analyzed on-line by gas chromatography in a GC-Agilent 7890A gas chromatographer with two columns in parallel, HP Plot-Q (19095-Q04, 30 m length, 0.530 mm I.D.) and HP-Molesieve (19095P-MSO, 30 m length, 0.530 mm I.D.), equipped with TCD and FID detectors. Reaction metrics: The total conversion percentage was determined using (4) % t o t a l c o n v e r s i o n = ( X i − X f X i ) * 100 , where X i is the initial heptane mass and X f is the final heptane mass. The selectivity percentage of each product, i, was found according to (5) % s e l e c t i v i t y o f i = ( C a t o m s i n s p e c i e s i C a t o m s p r o d u c e d i n t h e p r o d u c t s ) * 100 , where species i refers to ethylene, ethane, methane, propane, iso-butane, n-butane and n-hexane. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural studies The textural properties measured during N2 adsorption and desorption at 77K, included BET surface areas, micropore and total pore volumes, and the average pore diameters over the prepared monometallic and bimetallic catalysts as well as the parent zeolites; values are reported in Table 1 . It is evident that the BET surface area increases with the increase in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio from 5 to 80, for both the parent zeolites (from 399 to 630 m2/g), monometallic (from 409 to 623 m2/g) and bimetallic (from 506 to 650 m2/g) catalysts, due to the changes in the zeolite Y framework that take place as the Si substitutes the Al. The BET surface areas of the zeolites generally decrease upon impregnation with Ni metal, due to slight pore blockage as Ni particles deposit on the micropores of the zeolite, and this is most pronounced in the ZY60 support (from 643 to 601 m2/g). Although the BET surface area can potentially increase upon metal loading due to the own texture of the metal oxide added to that of the zeolite, the pore blockage effect seems to be more pronounced. While the micropore volumes are quite similar for all the prepared catalysts, the mesopore volume, and thus the total volume, seem to increase significantly with the increase in Si/Al ratio, and are also larger for the bimetallic catalysts in comparison with the monometallic ones. Surface area and porosity is known to have a strong effect on the metal dispersion (D m) and thus on the catalytic activity of supported mono/bimetallic catalysts, particularly in the case of structural sensitive reactions [37]. The larger BET surface areas and porosity values for the bimetallic catalysts, in accordance with studies from the literature [38], are a result of the improved metal dispersion, as discussed in Section 3.5. The average pore diameters are also wider for bimetallic catalysts and increase with the Si/Al ratio in consistency with the increase in the wider mesopores, as also indicated by the pore size distributions showing higher pore volume at each diameter for the higher Si/Al zeolites. Fig. 2 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms as well as the BJH pore and HK micropore size distributions for the monometallic (Fig. 2 a, c, e) and bimetallic catalysts (Fig. 2 b, d, f), respectively. According to the IUPAC classification, the NiO-ZY5 and NiO-WO3-ZY5 catalysts are between types I and IV while all the other plotted isotherms are of type IV illustrating mesoporous materials. Type I is attributed to microporous materials indicating that the ZY5 supports, with the lowest Si/Al ratio tend to behave more as microporous zeolites in comparison to the other supports, which is consistent with their significantly lower meso-pore volumes (0.06-0.08 cm3/g) listed in Table 1. The rest of the isotherms are clearly type IV and have H3 type hysteresis loops due to the presence of slit-shaped pores [39]. In addition, higher levels of N2 adsorption are observed for the bimetallic catalysts and for the higher Si/Al ratio catalysts, despite NiO-WO3-ZY60 and NiO-WO3-ZY80 showing similar adsorption levels, in consistency with the reported surface areas and porosities in Table 1. 3.2 Structural and morphological studies The XRD diffractograms are shown in Fig. 3 for the (a) monometallic and (b) bimetallic catalysts. The presence of sharp peaks indicates that the crystallinities of all the prepared catalysts are maintained in their final form after metal(s) loading and calcination; this can also be observed from the parent zeolite XRD patterns in Fig. S1 (Supplementary Information). The major zeolite framework diffraction peaks are centered around 10.3°, 12.1°, 15.9°, 20.6°, and 24.1°. The diffraction peaks corresponding to the cubic NiO phase are in 37.5, 42.8, and 62.8 2θ and indexed as (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes, while those for hexagonal WO3 phase are in 23.7, 29.7, and 49.3 2θ and indexed for (020), (200), and (220) reflections marked in Fig. 3b [40], and the remaining peaks are associated with zeolite crystal structure. Since XRD was performed after calcination and before reducing the catalysts, the NiO phases are visible in the monometallic catalysts NiO-ZY5, NiO-ZY30, NiO-ZY60, and NiO-ZY80 (see Fig. 3a), whereas both the NiO and WO3 phases are expected to be present in the bimetallic catalysts NiO-WO3-ZY5, NiO-WO3-ZY30, NiO-WO3-ZY60, and NiO-WO3-ZY80 (see Fig. 3b). However, the high crystallinity attributed to the zeolite structure reduces the peak intensities representing the metal oxide phases, and may coincide with them, making it challenging to confirm the existence of NiO and WO3 or the alloyed phase. Additionally, NiO phases, in particular, are barely visible in the bimetallic catalysts due to the presence of NiO in relatively low quantity compared to the monometallic catalysts. This is in agreement with the Ni loading effect on crystal phase growth reported in a previous study [41]. It is worth mentioning that XRD is mainly utilized herein to confirm the crystallinity of the catalysts and to identify the planes of zeolite rather than indicating the presence of NiO or WO3. Thus, the XPS analysis (see Section 3.3) will be utilized to study the surface elemental composition of the catalysts, while the TEM analysis (see Fig. 6) will confirm the existence of the Ni-W alloyed phase. Fig. 4 shows the Raman spectra obtained for the (a) monometallic and (b) bimetallic catalysts within the region 50-1000 cm−1. The Raman spectrum for zeolite Y often shows three peaks at 115, 303, and 502 cm−1 [21], however, these can get shifted upon metal deposition. As shown in Fig. 4 these peaks are centered around 129, 304 and 500 cm−1 for the monometallic catalysts, and around 120, 305, and 500 cm−1 for the bimetallic catalysts. Metal (Ni, W) doping into the zeolite lattice upon impregnation causes a shift towards higher wavenumber peaks and reflects induced local lattice strains, causing in turn changes in local bond strengths [42]. The Raman spectrum of nickel oxide has bands at 440 cm−1 of transverse optical type, and at 560 cm−1 of longitudinal optical type [43]. The larger presence of NiO in the monometallic catalysts leads to a broader peak at 500 cm−1 in the monometallic as compared to the bimetallic catalysts’ Raman spectra. Moreover, the peak between 270-320 cm−1 in the bimetallic catalysts are stronger in comparison to the monometallic counterparts, which is attributed to the O-W-O bending modes as a result of the presence of WO3 [44]. Studies have shown that the most intense bands of zeolite Y Raman spectrum at 504, 356 and 305 cm−1 result from the vibration of six-membered rings of the zeolite Y framework structure [45]. It was also suggested that the position of the mentioned bands might depend on the degree of zeolite hydration, and on the related position of the cations in the zeolite framework [45]. Further, a number of weak bands exist between 600-1000 cm−1 for the bimetallic catalysts that are attributed to the W oxides. In particular, the band at around 960 cm−1 is assigned to the symmetric stretch of W=O bond, and this band changes based on the predominance of WO4 (951 cm–1) or WO6 species (975 cm–1) [46]. Thus, a band in the range of 951 and 975 cm–1 is caused by a mixture of WO4 and WO6 species and can shift in position as the WO6/WO4 ratio changes [46]. The presence of WO4 suggests the formation of a NiWO4 phase, further indicating that an interaction between nickel and tungsten ions took place. Fig. S2 (Supplementary Information) and Fig. 5 show the HR-SEM images of the monometallic, and bimetallic catalysts, respectively, along with the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analysis obtained after area scanning, in order to average the elemental compositions of the materials. Zeolite Y particles of their well-known tetrahedral structure are clearly visible in the images, while the metal oxides (NiO, WO3) are hardly visible due to their much smaller size. Therefore EDX was carried out on the samples to confirm the presence of the chemical elements and loaded metals (Ni, W) as well as estimate their weight percentages, as shown in Table 2 . Although the reported weight percentages vary from a location to another across the same materials, these are average results from a number of EDX point analysis scans. In the monometallic catalysts, the Ni loading is around 5 wt%, very close to their nominal values (intended composition during preparation step). Besides, the bimetallic catalysts more or less achieved a total of 5 wt% metal loading with Ni:W ratio of 1:3, as seen from Table 2, indicating successful wet impregnation of the synthesized catalysts. The Si/Al molar ratio has been calculated from the EDX results by using the weight % of Si and Al, and added for all the materials in Table 2. These molar percentages agree to a great extent with the nominal molar ratios reported by the supplier. Fig. S3 (Supplementary Information) presents TEM images of (a) r-NiO-ZY30, and (b)-(c) r- NiO-WO3-ZY30 at different magnification levels. The tetrahedral zeolite particles, as shown in the low magnification images (a) and (b), are doped with clusters of heavier particles (darker areas) that are attributed to the metal oxides impregnated on these zeolite particles. While the dispersion is not clearly visible in these images, a high magnification image (c) portrays well-dispersed (darker) metal spots in the size of few nanometers, which shall be further discussed in the H2-TPD study (Section 3.5). The HR-TEM images imply successful metal impregnation on the zeolite particles, yet, the verification of the Ni-W alloying cannot be done from Fig. S3 as it would require advanced TEM techniques. For this reason, TEM-energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (TEM-EDX) and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) and STEM were employed for r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 (reduced at 500°C for 3h under 10% H2 in Ar) and are shown in Fig. 6 , where (a), (b) present HR-TEM images, (c) EDX analysis, (d) low magnification HAADF STEM, (e) a HAADF-STEM showing an area for Ni and W mapping and the corresponding EELS elemental maps of (f) Ni, (g) W, and (h) O. While Fig. 6a shows the metal (Ni and/or W) nanoparticles loaded on the zeolite surface, Fig. 6b shows the zeolite crystal structure confirming that upon the synthesis of Ni-W loaded zeolite particles, the crystal structure of the zeolite was intact; i.e. its crystallinity was preserved. In Fig. 6c the EDX spectrum taken from a typical zeolite particle (shown as an embedded image) is presented to reveal the composition of the catalyst, and it shows the presence of both Ni and W on the zeolite surface. Yet, it wouldn't be possible to distinguish the presence of bimetallic Ni/W phase or rather single metal (separate Ni and W) nanoparticles without utilizing EELS analysis. Thus, HAADF STEM imaging was done (Fig. 6d) showing the distribution of Ni and W particles on zeolites, from which an area was selected (shown in the yellow rectangle) for Ni and W mapping. This area is shown in Fig. 6e, indicating the presence of five nanoparticles of larger size (marked by the colored circles). Other small W particles are also visible in the W mapping but are too small (below 1 nm). The EELS elemental mapping for the selected region reveals that there is 1 pure Ni nanoparticle (red circle), 1 pure W nanoparticle (green circle) and 3 alloyed Ni-W nanoparticles (yellow circles) suggesting the existence of bimetallic phase of Ni-W, approximated, after repeating the analysis for several regions, as 60% of the total metal loading. Moreover, elemental mapping of O was done (Fig. 6h) to portray the zeolite signal. Table 3 lists the EDX quantitative weight and atomic percentages along with the uncertainties for r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 obtained after the EDX-TEM over the region in Fig. 6c. The table shows that the Si/Al ratios determined from both weight and atomic % are consistent with their corresponding nominal values. Also, the weight % of W/Ni is around 3 as intended for upon preparation. 3.3 Surface elemental composition and chemical state XPS was performed on selected reduced catalysts in an attempt to build an in-depth understanding of the surface elemental composition and bonding environment. Table 4 lists the surface elemental compositions and the corresponding core level binding energies of r-NiO-ZY5, r-NiO-ZY30, r-NiO-ZY80, and r-NiO-WO3-ZY30. Moreover, the detailed scans of XPS of Ni 2p, W 4f, Si 2p, and O 1s are presented in Fig. 7 for r-NiO- ZY30 and r-NiO-WO3-ZY30. The binding energies of O 1s reported in Table 4 were centered at 532.0 eV for r-NiO-ZY5 and shift to higher values of 532.8 ± 0.1 eV for r-NiO-ZY30, r-NiO-ZY80 and r-NiO-WO3-ZY30. These binding energies, with their slight variations, correspond to the oxygen framework of the zeolite structure [47]. The observed increase in O 1s binding energy for higher Si/Al ratios is consistent with Al2O3 expected at a binding energy of 531.1 eV [48] and SiO2 at a binding energy of 532.8 eV [49]. The Si 2p peaks for the analyzed materials are 102.7 eV for r-NiO-ZY5 (representing Si 2p3/2-oxide), and between 103.3-103.6 eV for r-NiO-ZY30, r-NiO-ZY80, and r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 (representing Si 2p1/2-oxide). The Si/Al atomic ratios of the materials were determined from the XPS results and are listed in Table 4, showing a similar trend of increasing Si/Al ratios as those expected from the nominal Si/Al ratios of the zeolite-Y supports (as reported by the supplier). However, the Si/Al ratios are not in very good agreement with the specific nominal values due to the XPS concentrations originating from the surface (analysis depth ∼5 nm). Results more consistent with the nominal values are those determined by EDX analysis in Section 3.2, as EDX has a much greater analysis depth, typically 1-2 µm. The XPS Si/Al ratios exhibit higher concentrations of Si at the surface, mainly attributed to the preparation methods and treatments of zeolite Y, including de-alumination. The Ni 2p3/2 peaks for the monometallic catalysts show a peak or shoulder at ∼853 eV, corresponding to metallic Ni (Fig. 7 and Fig. S4, Supplementary Information). There is then a broad peak at higher binding energies 855-857 eV. Various possible nickel oxide/hydroxide species exist having similar binding energies and complex peak shapes. The peak positions and shapes for the solids would imply a mix of Ni2+/Ni3+ oxides and hydroxides present at the surface [50-52] (hydroxide layer typically forms and chemisorbs on the surface of the oxide due to ambient air exposure). When comparing the monometallic and bimetallic catalysts having the same zeolite support, r-NiO-ZY30 exhibits a peak position of 855.9 eV compared to 858.0 eV for r-NiO-WO3-ZY30, suggesting the presence of Ni3+ for r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 [48], possibly either as NiOOH or due to Ni-W electronic interaction. However, this is a particularly high binding energy for Ni oxide/hydroxide species and the very low concentrations of Ni and W in r-NiO-WO3-ZY30, resulting in low signal-to-noise for the Ni 2p spectrum brings this binding energy into doubt. (The lower Ni concentration in r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 (0.2 at%) results from the W metal introduced to the catalyst as to achieve 5 wt.% total metal loading (Ni:W, 1:3 weight % ratio) where less Ni resides on the surface, while Ni concentration in r-NiO-ZY30 is 1.3 at%). A similar peak position difference is also observed for r-NiO-ZY5, 857.1 eV, as compared to r-NiO-ZY80, 854.8 eV (Fig. S4, Supplementary Information). The W 4f peak in Fig. 7b shows the W 4f7/2 and 4f5/2 doublet, W 4f7/2 peak position of 36.3 eV, which is consistent with W in its 6+ oxidation state [53]. 3.4 Monitoring and evaluating catalyst surface acidity through TPD-NH3 The TPD-NH3 is a conventional method for characterizing total acidity in zeolites [54]. The quantity of desorbed ammonia at a certain temperature range represents a measure of the acid site concentration, while the temperature range at which most of the ammonia is desorbed designates the acid strength distribution. According to the literature, the intensity of the low-temperature peaks in the NH3-TPD profiles (depicting weak acid sites) decreases with increasing Si/Al ratio in zeolites whereas the high-temperature peaks (depicting strong acid sites) broaden and shift to higher temperatures, indicating an increase in the acidic strength [55]. This trend is confirmed here for both monometallic and bimetallic catalysts, as seen from the NH3-TPD profiles presented Fig. 8 . While the desorption peaks in the low-temperature range, 100-300°C, correspond to weak acid sites, the higher temperature region peaks, 300-600°C, correspond to medium/strong acid sites [56,57]. Above 600°C, the peaks observed can be attributed to possible formation of N2 and NOx from the decomposition of adsorbed NH3 on the catalyst's surface, and thus these are not included in the acidity quantification in Table 5 [58]. The catalysts considered herein show a wide range of acid sites of various strengths (weak, medium, strong). The major peaks around the 100°C are in accordance with the TPD-NH3 studies for protonated Ni-ZY in literature [59]. A consistent shift in the NH3 desorption peaks towards higher temperatures is evident for the NiO-ZY30, NiO-ZY60, and NiO-ZY80 as compared to NiO-ZY5; a similar shift is also visible in the bimetallic catalytic system, indicating that stronger adsorption of NH3 occurs in the higher Si/Al catalysts. Also, the NiO-ZY5 and NiO-WO3-ZY5 catalysts with the lowest Si/Al ratio supports show rather 2 peaks as compared to 3 peaks for the other supports, indicating that the former have lower distribution of the acid site strengths. Nevertheless, NH3-TPD cannot distinguish the type of acid sites but rather the strength of these sites and total amount of acidity. For instance, the high temperature peaks are attributed to the desorption of ammonia from both strong Bronsted and Lewis acid sites, while the low temperature peaks are related to the adsorption of ammonia on weak acid sites such as Bronsted and Lewis sites, silanol groups, and to the formation of NH+4 (NH3)n (n ≥ 1) groups [60]. The loaded metal species can alter the acidities of the samples. It was observed that, as the amount of Ni increases, the total amount of acidic sites decreases with a minor decrease in the acidic strength, represented by a shift of the desorption peaks towards lower temperatures. Simultaneously, an increase in the proportion of weak sites, represented by desorption peaks at low temperature, was also shown with Ni incorporation [61]. Ni ions act as Lewis acid centers upon impregnation on zeolites [62]. Additionally, it was predicted that two Brønsted acid sites are created through the hydrolysis of each incorporated Ni2+ ion in the Ni-zeolite supported catalyst [63,64]. However, upon metal impregnation, acid sites of the zeolite can be blocked by the metal which might lead to a reduction in the acidity after the Ni and W incorporation [65]. It was also reported that the weak acid site number increased with WO3 loading whereas the strong acid site number decreased. The lower amount of strong acid sites may be due to blockage and deactivation of Brønsted acid sites by the aggregation of WO3 species [66]. It is worth noting that upon reduction in H2, WOx will be reduced to form WOx-y and some W=O will produce W-OH, increasing the Bronsted acidity. Based on the previous discussion, it can be concluded that Ni or W incorporation increase the weak acid sites while decreasing the strong acid sites, yet, the change in total acidity depends on the proportion of zeolite acid sites getting blocked as a result of the metal impregnation. It can be shown by the acidity breakdown in Table 5 that bimetallic catalysts, as compared to their monometallic counterpart, showed an increase in strong acid sites and a decrease in medium acid sites for the same zeolite support. However, when comparing the total acidities, a trend cannot be established, as NiO-WO3-ZY5 and NiO-WO3-ZY30 had lower total acidity than their monometallic counterpart, while NiO-WO3-ZY60, and NiO-WO3-ZY80 showed opposite trends. The amount of desorbed ammonia is determined by calculating the areas under the peaks for all catalysts and are presented in Table 5. The quantified global acidity generally increased with an increase in Si/Al of the support, yet, a drop in acidity was noticed for the ZY30 support in NiO-ZY30 and NiO-WO3-ZY30. It is worth mentioning that the quantified acid sites here are not all attributed to the Al sites, since studies have shown that upon quantification, the total amount of NH3 adsorbed was found to be in excess of the number of Al atoms/g, suggesting that part of the adsorbed NH3 is physically adsorbed on sites such as silanol groups [67]. This explains why the total amount of NH3 adsorbed increased with the increase in Si/Al ratio, although the number of acid sites are expected to decrease with this change in ratio. 3.5 Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of H2 Temperature programmed desorption of H2 (TPD-H2) profiles are shown in Fig. 9 , for selected reduced catalysts (at 500°C for 3h under 10% H2 in Ar) of this study, namely r-NiO-ZY30 and r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 (Ni:W, 1:3). Those catalysts were chosen to study the bimetallicity impact on the metal dispersion and metal particle size. Since the same metal impregnation technique was used for all catalysts, the TPD-H2 study was not performed for the other catalysts considered herein. Fig. 9 shows that both catalysts reveal two broad overlapping H2 desorption peaks in the temperature region of 100-400 °C. These peaks are slightly shifted to higher temperatures for the case of the bimetallic r-NiO-WO3-ZY30, revealing electronic interaction between Ni/NiO and W/WO3, causing the H2 desorption to occur at a higher temperature (i.e stronger chemisorption of H2 for the bimetallic catalyst). The deconvolutions of the broad peaks are shown in Fig. 9c and d, where the first peaks at around 245 and 300 °C in r-NiO-ZY30 and r-NiO-WO3-ZY30, respectively, are attributed to H2 chemisorbed on the Ni surface, while the second peaks at around 325 and 360 °C are associated with the H2 held between the Ni metal and the zeolite support (interfacial hydrogen) [68]. H2 desorption peaks from W metal are estimated to be between 272-302 °C as well [69]. Another peak is seen to initiate at around ∼550 °C and is related to the H2 species on the support away from the Ni particles arising from Ni-support interaction, or may result from H2 spillover and/or reoxidation of Ni by water inherent on the catalyst after reduction [70]. Studies have shown that TPD-H2 patterns of pure nano-sized nickel catalyst (prepared from alkaline nickel carbonate) reveal a desorption peak at around 130 °C, while that for Ni-W catalysts (prepared by mixing alkaline nickel carbonate with a solution of ammonium tungstate) show three main desorption peaks centered at around 130, 245 and 305 °C [38], the latter two are similar to the peak positions reported herein while the first is rather a low-intensity peak in the bimetallic catalyst. Upon the addition of W to the Ni-based catalyst, where separate Ni and W phases as well as reduced NiWO4 phases exist, the quantity of adsorbed hydrogen increases and thus, it is predicted that the hydrogen adsorption sites of the catalysts increase [38]. The dispersion percentage (D m), and the particle size of Ni in the r-NiO-ZY30 catalyst were evaluated using the chemisorbed H2 in the TPD-H2 study by applying Eqs. (2) and (3). The obtained values show that Ni particles were poorly dispersed in the r-NiO-ZY30 catalyst (D m ∼4.1%, and particle size of Ni ∼24 nm), yet, the dispersion was better for the r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 catalyst (D m ∼7.0%, and average particle size of Ni,W ∼14 nm). It is known that the nickel in Ni-zeolite systems forms rather poorly dispersed and large Ni0 particles (20−30 nm), in agreement with our reported range for the monometallic catalyst, as widely reported in literature [71–73]. After reduction under H2, Ni0 particles and Ni0-W0 alloyed particles were formed and favored in r-NiO-ZY30 and r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 catalysts, respectively. Upon analyzing the EELS elemental mapping in Figs. 6 f and g for Ni and W respectively, the main nanoparticles analyzed are around 20 nm in size. However, W shows many smaller particles in the range of only few nanometers that are well dispersed on the zeolite surface, as seen from the images. It is expected, as reported in literature [38], that adding tungsten to nickel-based catalyst considerably increases its BET surface area, as reported in Table 1, along with smaller metal particle size and more uniform distribution, as displayed by Fig. 6g. Thus, the presence of W impacts the overall metal distribution in r-NiO-WO3-ZY30, which subsequently affects the acid properties of the catalyst, as Ni-W in the alloy or Ni2+-W6+ in the oxide phases compensate framework charge, and the concentrations of surface acid sites in the intra-zeolitic space (micropores) and in the mesopores are altered. Further, studies have shown that the Ni-W alloy hinders coke production attributed to the formation of tungsten carbide (WC) by CO2 dissociation [74,75]. Also, the Ni-W phase is thermally stable at elevated temperature ranges [76]. Another study reported that the addition of W into Ni-based catalyst enriched the degree of reduction as predicted by the TPR results, suggesting the availability of more active Ni sites for the reaction [77]. Their TPD-CO2 results revealed that upon the addition of W, the basicity of the catalyst was reduced; arising from the acidic nature of tungsten oxide, which is consistent with the acidity results of the bimetallic and monometallic catalysts reported in Section 3.4. 3.6 Catalytic performance Fig. 10 shows the heptane conversion and the selectivity towards various reaction products at the two tested temperatures of 350 and 400°C over the reduced monometallic (Fig. 10 a, c) and reduced bimetallic catalysts (Fig. 10 b, d); the main results are also summarized in Table 6 . After 3 h time-on-stream, the conversion ranged from 62.3% to 79.4% for the reduced monometallic catalysts and from 77.8% to 86.3% for the reduced bimetallic catalysts at 350°C. At 400°C the conversion varied from 74.2% to 82.7% for the reduced monometallic catalysts, and from 78.2% to 90.6% for the reduced bimetallic catalysts. This suggests that, overall, bimetallic catalysts were more catalytically active during hydrocracking due to the enhanced effect of Ni-W mixed phase, as widely reported in literature [25,28]. The Ni-W interaction creates both electronic and geometric effects which play a role in the improved catalytic performance of the bimetallic catalysts. The former effect causes a decrease in the electron density of Ni atoms, whereas the geometric effect results in an increase in the BET surface areas of the bimetallic catalysts (see Section 3.1) due to their more uniform metal dispersion and smaller particle size (see Section 3.5). Also, higher conversion levels are reported for all catalysts at 400°C as compared to 350°C. Among the tested temperatures, the best performing catalyst in terms of conversion was r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 (86.3% at 350°C and 90.6% at 400°C), while the least active were r-NiO-ZY30 (62.3%) at 350°C and r-NiO-ZY5 (74.2%) at 400°C. In comparison to the other catalysts, r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 exhibits a remarkable high-intensity NH3 desorption peak at around 400°C which can be linked to its highest conversion level. Even though some exceptions exist, the general trend shows an increase in conversion with the increase in Si/Al ratio, especially for the monometallic catalysts, which can be attributed to the higher strength of Brønsted acid sites for high-Si supports, even if lower number of these sites are available (see Section 3.4). Conversion and selectivity of hydrocracking catalysts are generally influenced by a number of factors such as porosity, strength of the active sites, hydrogenation to acidity ratio, or proximity between the two catalytic functions [14]. In a study where hydrocracking of n-decane was performed using sulfided NiW/zeolite Y catalysts (at 380 °C, 6 MPa), it was observed that the isomerization/cracking ratio (I/C) decreased regularly as the conversion of n-decane increased [78]. At n-decane conversion of 24%, the main products were C4, C5, and C6 with selectivity of 26, 31, and 25 mol %, respectively. In a different study, the hydrocracking of tetralin (at 350 °C, 6MPa) over sulfided Ni-W/zeolite Y catalyst was measured to be around 45% with the highest selectivity being towards heavy compounds, benzene and alkyl benzene [79]. Variations in the support and the doped metal(s) in the prepared catalysts are expected to lead to different product distributions which is reflected by the selectivity percentages shown in Fig. 10. In general, the selectivity towards n-hexane decreased, and that towards ethane and ethylene increased, with the increase in Si/Al ratio at both temperatures. Also, the r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 catalyst having the best conversion, showed relatively low selectivity towards methane (0.8-0.9%) and higher selectivity towards ethylene (2.1-3%) at 350 and 400°C. The r-NiO-ZY5 catalyst with lowest conversion at 400°C, in contrast, was the most selective towards propane molecules (reaching 52% at 400°C). These observations are correlated to the pore distribution of the tested catalysts as shown earlier in Section 3.1. The product distributions of the cracked products in terms of carbon number constitute of C1, C2, C3, C4, and C6. In this case, a symmetrical distribution should be found centered at C3, with C2 and C4, C1 and C6 having equal amounts in order to have only primary cracking. However, the high content of C4 products makes the distribution asymmetrical, indicating the existence of secondary cracking [28]. Yet, the presence of methane as a product shows that direct cracking mechanism has occurred [78], since hypothetically, methane is not a cracking product through carbenium ion mechanism. As explained above, the textural properties indicate that all the prepared catalysts have some degree of meso-porosity and micro-porosity, yet, the level of each varies from one support to another, mainly induced by the different zeolite structures and Si/Al ratios. It is clear that the catalysts with ZY5 support (lowest Si/Al ratio) contain mainly micro-pores (pore volume 0.19-0.23 cm3/g) and have the lowest meso-porosity (pore volume 0.06-0.08 cm3/g) and total pore volume (0.25-0.31 cm3/g), as reported in Table 1. The other supports provide a rather balanced ratio of micropores and mesopores (hierarchical pore system) with the most reactive catalyst, NiO-WO3-ZY30, having a well-adjusted distribution of 0.23 cm3/g micropore volume and 0.21 cm3/g mesopore volume, and thus a total pore volume of 0.44 cm3/g. The catalyst porosity indeed affects the product distribution in hydrocracking, as it impacts the reaction mechanism pathway when certain reactants/products are permitted or inhibited depending on the pore size of the support. It has been reported in the literature that acidic characteristics of the support, and thus Si/Al ratio, are highly correlated to the catalytic performance. The NH3-TPD profiles reported in this study (see Fig. 8) showed that, with increasing Si/Al ratio of the ZY support, the intensity of the low-temperature peaks (representing weak acid sites) decreased and the high-temperature peaks (representing strong acid sites) shifted to higher temperatures, demonstrating an improvement in the acidic strength, which agreed well with the total acidity quantification. This, in turn, increases their catalytic activity since strong acid sites facilitate the cracking function of the catalyst. In particular, after migrating to a Brønsted acid site, a heptane molecule undergoes protonation to form a carbenium ion, which then undergoes a series of reaction steps. For instance, these ions can get isomerized via alkyl shifts or protonated cyclopropane (PCP) steps, and are then cracked into smaller molecules through β-scission forming olefins and shorter carbenium ions [80]. Further cracking of the olefins later occurs on the acid sites, or alternatively, olefins can get hydrogenated over Ni metal sites [80], whereas carbenium ions can be deprotonated forming olefins, which then form paraffins through hydrogenation steps [80]. In this study, the main olefin produced, ethylene, was seen to be related to the metallic phase on the catalyst, in which the selectivity towards ethylene increased over the bimetallic (Ni-W) based catalysts as compared to the monometallic (Ni) counterparts, as shown in Fig. 10. Long stability tests, i.e., 20 h, were also performed for the reduced monometallic and reduced bimetallic catalysts; these tests were carried out at 400°C and the results are presented in Fig. 11 . As can be observed, the drop in conversion is more pronounced for the r-NiO -ZY5 (from 74.8% to 56.6%, a drop of 18.2%) and r-NiO-WO3-ZY5 (from 76.1% to 63.1%, a drop of 13%), due to these catalysts having zeolite Y support of relatively low Si/Al ratio, [13], which means that they have fewer Si–O–Si than Si–O–Al linkages [9]. In general, as the Si/Al ratio increased among the catalysts’ support, the stability was improved, yet the r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 catalyst showed remarkable stability with time (from 89.9% to 88.9%, a drop of 1%). In all cases, the conversion drop is attributed to the carbonaceous deposition on the catalysts with time-on-stream, blocking some of the active sites available for hydrocracking. This can possibly happen through Ni carburization or plugging of the zeolite porosity. Acidity of the zeolites can contribute too to the coke formation and thus to the drop in conversion with time. It was investigated that coke is generated due to reactions occurring in the inner zeolite cavity/channel at acidic sites and over the zeolite external surfaces [81]. 4 Conclusions In this work, hydrocracking of heptane was performed at two temperatures (350°C and 400°C) using a series of monometallic (Ni) and bimetallic (Ni, W) bi-functional catalysts. In each of these systems, zeolite Y supports were used with various SiO2/Al2O3 ratios, namely 5, 30, 60, and 80. The measured conversion and selectivity percentages of the prepared catalysts were compared and discussed in relation to their bulk and surface properties. Heptane conversion ranged from 74.2% to 82.7% for reduced monometallic catalysts, and from 78.2% to 90.6% for reduced bimetallic catalysts at 400°C, with the highest conversion reported over r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 (86.3% at 350°C and 90.6% at 400°C), and the lowest over r-NiO-ZY5 (74.2%) at 400°C; the different performance is attributed to the stronger acidity, higher porosity, and better metal dispersion of the former. Moreover, the NH3-TPD profile of the r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 showed a high-intensity NH3 desorption peak at around 400°C which could have contributed to the observed change in the heptane conversion level. As the Si/Al ratio of the zeolite Y support increased, the selectivity towards ethane and ethylene increased while that for n-hexane decreased at both reaction temperatures considered herein. Further, the catalyst support with the lowest Si/Al ratio, ZY5, had the lowest meso-porosity (pore volume 0.06-0.08 cm3/g) and total pore volume (0.25-0.31 cm3/g), in addition to lower acidic strength compared to the other supports, leading to its reduced catalytic activity during the reaction. The NH3-TPD study revealed that with increasing Si/Al ratio of ZY support, the intensity of the low-temperature peaks (representing weak acid sites) decreased and the high-temperature peaks (representing strong acid sites) shifted to higher temperatures, demonstrating an increase in the acidic strength. Stability results indicated that the drop in conversion with time was more pronounced in r-NiO -ZY5 (from 74.8% to 56.6%, a drop of 18.2%) and r-NiO-WO3-ZY5 (from 76.1% to 63.1%, a drop of 13%), having lowest Si/Al ratio, while r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 was the most stable with time with a drop of around 1% due to its enhanced support characteristics. The findings of this study suggest that the optimized composition r-NiO-WO3-ZY30 catalyst, performed best in terms of activity and stability, and that relatively low Si/Al ratio zeolites can suffer from stability issues upon hydrocracking. In the future, the catalyst design concepts used in this study can be extended to study the hydrocracking of more complex molecules, and to optimize for a different combinations of metals and supports. coredata.dc:description: This study investigated the effect of the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio in the range of 5-80 in zeolite Y (ZY) as a support for the bi-functional reaction of heptane hydrocracking. Bi-metallicity impact, through the addition of W on Ni in the supported metal catalysts was also examined. The catalytic activity was assessed at 350°C and 400°C in order to deduce an optimized composition of the catalyst in terms of metal composition and Si/Al ratio. The results were correlated to the catalysts’ surface and bulk properties, the latter after employing a number of material characterization techniques. It was shown that Ni-W bimetallic catalysts demonstrated better catalytic activity (conversion, 78% to 91%) than Ni-based monometallic counterpart catalysts (conversion, 74.2% to 82.7%), with NiO-WO3-ZY30 (SiO2/Al2O3 ratio equal to 30) exhibiting the highest conversion. This was attributed to the bimetallic's enhanced metal dispersion and smaller particle size, evaluated using temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of H2 and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) imaging. The stronger acidity, as quantified by total acidity calculations, of zeolite Y having higher Si/Al ratio, and their balanced ratio of micro- and meso-porosity played a vital role in their catalytic performance. This study provides useful design guidelines on how to adjust both the Si/Al ratio in the zeolite Y support and the catalyst's bimetallicity for enhanced hydrocracking performance.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of SiO2/Al2O3 ratio in Ni/Zeolite-Y and Ni-W/Zeolite-Y catalysts on hydrocracking of heptane
